COIN CASES DONATED

An important gift has just been received by the University, from Mr.
William H. Buckler, one of the trustees. During Mr. Buckler's residence
in Spain, he spent considerable time
in making a valuable collection of
the ancient coins of that country,
more than three thousand of which
he presented to the University about
a year ago. These coins bear inscriptions in four different languages
—Latin, Greek, Celtiberian, and
Phcenician. For lack of a suitable
place to deposit them, these coins
have been lying in the vaults of the
Treasurer's office, but this will now
be no longer necessary. Two weeks
ago, on his arrival in this country,
Mr. Buckler brought with him six
beautiful cabinets of mahogany, similar to those which are used to house
the coin collection of the British Museum. These cases have altogether
a capacity of nearly six thousand
coins, so that the present needs of the
University coin collections are provided for.
These gifts bring the Johns Hopkins to the first place among the American universities, so far as the collection of ancient coins is concerned. There is only one other American collection of ancient coins of
Spain which is in any sense comparable with this, namely, the Hispanic
Society in New York.

The introduction of the Honor System at the Lnivers,ty is a question
which deserves some attention when
we consider that this practice is being adopted in more and more of the
colleges throughout the country. The
Honor System exists, naturally, for
the benefit of the man who does not
'cheat, not for the weaker individual.
Yet its workings, in the case of the
discovery of a culprit, are silent,practical, fair in application, and certain
in results. The center of action of
such a system lies in a committee,
composed of delegates elected by the
different classes. If a student is accused of cheating„ he is brought before the committee, and tried in secret. If found guilty, his name is
reported by the commiAee to the
Dean, who arranges for the boy to
flunk out of college at the next examination. All knowledge of the affair is confined to the commitee, the
men at the trial, the Dean, and the
members of the faculty who arrange
to "flunk out" the culprit. These men
are in honor bound to Reep the matter secret, and the boy leaves college
free to start over -again somewhere,
without the reputation of a cheat. The
system is as grim and noiseless as
the guillotine, but in one way more
merciful.
\\There such a system exists, supported by both faculty and students,
with absolutely no restraint placed on
a student in examinations, there are
at first several cases of heartburn and
sorrow which, however, are far offset
by the influence on the average student of the very existence and atmosphere of the Honor System around
him.
The initial point for the introduction of such a system lies, of course,
in discussion in class meetings.

the only colors into which rays of
light were decomposed, but that they
were those to which the eye was
sensible. He said that there are rays
beyond the spectrum which could be
seen by the eye. He explained how
pictures could be taken by means of
the ultra violet rays, if the spectrum
was made opaque to the sunlight.
Pictures could also be taken by means
of the infra red rays.
Doctor Wood presented a number
of interesting stereopticon views of
landscapes, taken by means of the
infra red and ultra violet rays. The
decided difference between the two
different types was very remarkable.
Pictures taken by means of the infra red rays gave the appearance of
snow scenes. While those taken with
the ultra violet rays produced pictures different from normal photographs or those taken with the infra

anticipation, and the praise, criticism and misrepresentation, alas!
which Dr. Slosson judicially deals
out goes a long way, but hardly fulfills our expectations. But our expectations were, perhaps, too large; our
knowledge of Hopkins—too expansive and accurate, to accept with
equanimity an exposition of our weaknesses as well as our virtues, of our
faults and failures as well as our successes. In addition, the article is
